npm i -g @openai/codex
or brew install --cask codex

Codex CLI is a coding agent from OpenAI that runs locally on your computer.

If you want Codex in your code editor (VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf), install in your IDE
If you are looking for the cloud-based agent from OpenAI, Codex Web, go to chatgpt.com/codex

--- ## Quickstart ### Installing and running Codex CLI Install globally with your preferred package manager. If you use npm: ```shell npm install -g @openai/codex ``` Alternatively, if you use Homebrew: ```shell brew install --cask codex ``` Then simply run `codex` to get started: ```shell codex ``` If you're running into upgrade issues with Homebrew, see the [FAQ entry on brew upgrade codex](./docs/faq.md#brew-upgrade-codex-isnt-upgrading-me).
You can also go to the latest GitHub Release and download the appropriate binary for your platform. Each GitHub Release contains many executables, but in practice, you likely want one of these: - macOS - Apple Silicon/arm64: `codex-aarch64-apple-darwin.tar.gz` - x86_64 (older Mac hardware): `codex-x86_64-apple-darwin.tar.gz` - Linux - x86_64: `codex-x86_64-unknown-linux-musl.tar.gz` - arm64: `codex-aarch64-unknown-linux-musl.tar.gz` Each archive contains a single entry with the platform baked into the name (e.g., `codex-x86_64-unknown-linux-musl`), so you likely want to rename it to `codex` after extracting it.
### Using Codex with your ChatGPT plan

Run `codex` and select **Sign in with ChatGPT**. We recommend signing into your ChatGPT account to use Codex as part of your Plus, Pro, Team, Edu, or Enterprise plan. [Learn more about what's included in your ChatGPT plan](https://help.openai.com/en/articles/11369540-codex-in-chatgpt). You can also use Codex with an API key, but this requires [additional setup](./docs/authentication.md#usage-based-billing-alternative-use-an-openai-api-key). If you previously used an API key for usage-based billing, see the [migration steps](./docs/authentication.md#migrating-from-usage-based-billing-api-key). If you're having trouble with login, please comment on [this issue](https://github.com/openai/codex/issues/1243). ### Model Context Protocol (MCP) Codex can access MCP servers. To configure them, refer to the [config docs](./docs/config.md#mcp_servers). ### Configuration Codex CLI supports a rich set of configuration options, with preferences stored in `~/.codex/config.toml`. For full configuration options, see [Configuration](./docs/config.md). ### Execpolicy See the [Execpolicy quickstart](./docs/execpolicy.md) to set up rules that govern what commands Codex can execute. ### Docs & FAQ - [**Getting started**](./docs/getting-started.md) - [CLI usage](./docs/getting-started.md#cli-usage) - [Slash Commands](./docs/slash_commands.md) - [Running with a prompt as input](./docs/getting-started.md#running-with-a-prompt-as-input) - [Example prompts](./docs/getting-started.md#example-prompts) - [Custom prompts](./docs/prompts.md) - [Memory with AGENTS.md](./docs/getting-started.md#memory-with-agentsmd) - [**Configuration**](./docs/config.md) - [Example config](./docs/example-config.md) - [**Sandbox & approvals**](./docs/sandbox.md) - [**Execpolicy quickstart**](./docs/execpolicy.md) - [**Authentication**](./docs/authentication.md) - [Auth methods](./docs/authentication.md#forcing-a-specific-auth-method-advanced) - [Login on a "Headless" machine](./docs/authentication.md#connecting-on-a-headless-machine) - **Automating Codex** - [GitHub Action](https://github.com/openai/codex-action) - [TypeScript SDK](./sdk/typescript/README.md) - [Non-interactive mode (`codex exec`)](./docs/exec.md) - [**Advanced**](./docs/advanced.md) - [Tracing / verbose logging](./docs/advanced.md#tracing--verbose-logging) - [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](./docs/advanced.md#model-context-protocol-mcp) - [**Zero data retention (ZDR)**](./docs/zdr.md) - [**Contributing**](./docs/contributing.md) - [**Install & build**](./docs/install.md) - [System Requirements](./docs/install.md#system-requirements) - [DotSlash](./docs/install.md#dotslash) - [Build from source](./docs/install.md#build-from-source) - [**FAQ**](./docs/faq.md) - [**Open source fund**](./docs/open-source-fund.md) --- ## License This repository is licensed under the [Apache-2.0 License](LICENSE).

   655	
   656	If you build Codex from source the OTEL crate is still behind an `otel` feature
   657	flag; the official prebuilt binaries ship with the feature enabled. When the
   658	feature is disabled the telemetry hooks become no-ops so the CLI continues to
   659	function without the extra dependencies.
   660	
   661	### notify
   662	
   663	Specify a program that will be executed to get notified about events generated by Codex. Note that the program will receive the notification argument as a string of JSON, e.g.:
   664	
   665	```json
   666	{
   667	  "type": "agent-turn-complete",
   668	  "thread-id": "b5f6c1c2-1111-2222-3333-444455556666",
   669	  "turn-id": "12345",
   670	  "cwd": "/Users/alice/projects/example",
   671	  "input-messages": ["Rename `foo` to `bar` and update the callsites."],
   672	  "last-assistant-message": "Rename complete and verified `cargo build` succeeds."
   673	}
   674	```
   675	
   676	The `"type"` property will always be set. Currently, `"agent-turn-complete"` is the only notification type that is supported.
   677	
   678	`"thread-id"` contains a string that identifies the Codex session that produced the notification; you can use it to correlate multiple turns that belong to the same task.
   679	
   680	`"cwd"` reports the absolute working directory for the session so scripts can disambiguate which project triggered the notification.
   681	
   682	As an example, here is a Python script that parses the JSON and decides whether to show a desktop push notification using [terminal-notifier](https://github.com/julienXX/terminal-notifier) on macOS:
   683	
   684	```python
   685	#!/usr/bin/env python3
   686	
   687	import json
   688	import subprocess
   689	import sys
   690	
   691	
   692	def main() -> int:
   693	    if len(sys.argv) != 2:
   694	        print("Usage: notify.py <NOTIFICATION_JSON>")
   695	        return 1
   696	
   697	    try:
   698	        notification = json.loads(sys.argv[1])
   699	    except json.JSONDecodeError:
   700	        return 1
   701	
   702	    match notification_type := notification.get("type"):
   703	        case "agent-turn-complete":
   704	            assistant_message = notification.get("last-assistant-message")
   705	            if assistant_message:
   706	                title = f"Codex: {assistant_message}"
   707	            else:
   708	                title = "Codex: Turn Complete!"
   709	            input_messages = notification.get("input-messages", [])
   710	            message = " ".join(input_messages)
   711	            title += message
   712	        case _:
   713	            print(f"not sending a push notification for: {notification_type}")
   714	            return 0
   715	
   716	    thread_id = notification.get("thread-id", "")
   717	
   718	    subprocess.check_output(
   719	        [
   720	            "terminal-notifier",
   721	            "-title",
   722	            title,
   723	            "-message",
   724	            message,
   725	            "-group",
   726	            "codex-" + thread_id,
   727	            "-ignoreDnD",
   728	            "-activate",
   729	            "com.googlecode.iterm2",
   730	        ]
   731	    )
   732	
   733	    return 0
   734	
   735	
   736	if __name__ == "__main__":
   737	    sys.exit(main())
   738	```

payload.text:
**Designing notify command to accept JSON arg**

PowerShell treats extra arguments after `-Command` as part of the command string causing parse errors, so ignoring JSON this way won't work. Using `bash -lc` to invoke PowerShell beep inside WSL prevents the JSON arg from interfering, offering a clean workaround for the beep notification despite codex passing JSON.

Next, I'll finalize the explanation in Japanese and mark the plan step as completed.

payload.message:
原因は2つあります。

- `/home/kei/.codex/config.toml:17` の `[notice]` 配下に `notify` を書いていたため、Codexが見る「トップレベルの `notify`」として解釈されず、そもそも発火していませんでした（`notify` はトップレベルキーです）。
- さらに `notify` に設定していた `afplay /System/Library/Sounds/Ping.aiff` は macOS 専用で、いまの環境は `Ubuntu 24.04 on WSL2` なので `afplay` も音源ファイルも存在せず、仮に呼ばれても鳴りません。

修正として、`notify` をトップレベルに移動し、WSLから確実に鳴らせるように Windows 側の `powershell.exe` でビープ音を出す設定に直しました: `/home/kei/.codex/config.toml:7`

- 変更後は `codex` を起動し直して試してください（設定は起動時に読み込まれます）。
- 手動テストするなら `bash -lc 'powershell.exe -NoProfile -Command "[console]::beep(1000,300)"'` を実行して鳴るか確認できます。

**Explaining updated notify sound with customization tips**

Changed notify sound to Windows built-in `Windows Notify System Generic.wav` at `/home/kei/.codex/config.toml:10` for a fresher tone. To use other sounds, just replace the filename there with options like `chimes.wav`, `ding.wav`, `tada.wav`, or `Windows Notify Email.wav`. You can preview sounds quickly in WSL with commands like:

```
powershell.exe -NoProfile -Command "(New-Object System.Media.SoundPlayer 'C:/Windows/Media/chimes.wav').PlaySync()"
```

After editing, restart Codex to apply changes. For toast plus sound notifications, ensure `tui.notifications=true`.

**Creating audio notification file**

I'm generating a WAV audio file named `codex_ai_notify.wav` in the user's `.codex` directory using Python 3.

payload.name: shell_command
payload.arguments:
{"command":"python3 - <<'PY'
import math, random, wave, struct, os

out_path = '/mnt/c/Users/key_u/.codex/codex_ai_notify.wav'
os.makedirs(os.path.dirname(out_path), exist_ok=True)

sr = 48000
length_s = 1.15
n = int(sr * length_s)

# Generate a rich, "AI-ish" sci‑fi notification: chirp + pad + shimmer + noise + echo
samples = [0.0] * n

phase = 0.0
phase2 = 0.0
pad_phase = 0.0

for i in range(n):
    t = i / sr

    # Envelope: fast attack, gentle decay
    env = (1.0 - math.exp(-t / 0.010)) * math.exp(-t / 0.65)

    # Piecewise frequency sweep (up then slight down)
    if t < 0.38:
        u = t / 0.38
        f = 520 + (1650 - 520) * (u ** 0.80)
    else:
        u = (t - 0.38) / (length_s - 0.38)
        f = 1650 + (900 - 1650) * (u ** 0.65)

    # Subtle vibrato + FM shimmer
    vibrato = 1.0 + 0.012 * math.sin(2 * math.pi * 6.0 * t)
    f *= vibrato

    # Main oscillator
    phase += 2 * math.pi * f / sr
    main = math.sin(phase)

    # Harmonic for brightness
    phase2 += 2 * math.pi * (f * 1.503) / sr
    bright = 0.55 * math.sin(phase2 + 0.35 * math.sin(2 * math.pi * 18.0 * t))

    # Soft pad underlay
    pad_f = 196.0
    pad_phase += 2 * math.pi * pad_f / sr
    pad_env = (1.0 - math.exp(-t / 0.030)) * math.exp(-t / 1.2)
    pad = 0.35 * pad_env * (math.sin(pad_phase) + 0.25 * math.sin(2 * pad_phase))

    # Air/noise swoosh (high frequency noise, decays quickly)
    noise = (random.random() * 2 - 1) * math.exp(-t / 0.10) * 0.08

    # Transient click (very short) to make it feel "snappy"
    click = 0.0
    if t < 0.008:
        click = (random.random() * 2 - 1) * (1 - t / 0.008) * 0.12

    s = env * (0.62 * main + 0.30 * bright) + pad + noise + click
    samples[i] = s

# Simple echo (two taps)
def add_delay(buf, delay_s, gain):
    d = int(sr * delay_s)
    if d <= 0:
        return
    for i in range(d, len(buf)):
        buf[i] += buf[i - d] * gain

add_delay(samples, 0.055, 0.30)
add_delay(samples, 0.110, 0.18)

# Soft limiter / normalize
peak = max(abs(x) for x in samples) or 1.0
scale = 0.92 / peak
samples = [x * scale for x in samples]

with wave.open(out_path, 'wb') as wf:
    wf.setnchannels(1)
    wf.setsampwidth(2)  # 16-bit
    wf.setframerate(sr)
    frames = bytearray()
    for x in samples:
        v = int(max(-1.0, min(1.0, x)) * 32767)
        frames += struct.pack('<h', v)
    wf.writeframes(frames)

print(out_path)
print('bytes', os.path.getsize(out_path))
PY","workdir":"/home/kei/.codex","timeout_ms":100000}

**Designing a new futuristic notification sound**

Planning to generate a new 1.2-second stereo WAV with rich FM synthesis, layered futuristic chords, noise sparkles, and stereo echo, saving it as a new file and updating the config notify line accordingly without overwriting existing extra config sections.

payload.name: shell_command
payload.arguments:
{"command":"python3 - <<'PY'
import math, random, wave, struct, os

out_path = '/mnt/c/Users/key_u/.codex/codex_ai_notify_future.wav'
os.makedirs(os.path.dirname(out_path), exist_ok=True)

sr = 48000
length_s = 1.25
n = int(sr * length_s)

L = [0.0] * n
R = [0.0] * n

twopi = 2.0 * math.pi

def env_perc(t: float, attack: float, decay: float) -> float:
    # Smooth percussive envelope
    return (1.0 - math.exp(-t / max(attack, 1e-6))) * math.exp(-t / max(decay, 1e-6))

# --- Main "UI laser" (FM chirp) ---
phaseL = 0.0
phaseR = 0.0
modPhase = 0.0

# --- Chord shimmer oscillators ---
ch_phases_L = [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]
ch_phases_R = [0.0, 0.0, 0.0]

# A slightly uncanny interval stack: root + tritone + octave+minor2
base = 698.46  # F5-ish
ch_freqs = [base, base * (2 ** (6/12)), base * 2 * (2 ** (1/12))]  # F5, B5(tritone), F#6

# Sparkle events
spark_events = []
random.seed(1337)
for _ in range(18):
    t0 = random.uniform(0.06, 0.75)
    dur = random.uniform(0.015, 0.050)
    freq = random.uniform(3200.0, 8200.0)
    amp = random.uniform(0.03, 0.09)
    pan = random.uniform(-1.0, 1.0)
    spark_events.append((t0, dur, freq, amp, pan))

# Pre-sort for early exit
spark_events.sort(key=lambda x: x[0])

# High-passed noise state
prev_noise = 0.0
hp = 0.0
hp_alpha = 0.995

for i in range(n):
    t = i / sr

    # FM chirp: fast and bright
    e_main = env_perc(t, 0.0045, 0.30)
    # Exponential sweep (clamped)
    f = 760.0 * (2.0 ** (t * 1.55))
    if f > 2600.0:
        f = 2600.0

    # Modulator (metallic) + index decay
    mod_f = f * 3.25
    modPhase += twopi * mod_f / sr
    mod = math.sin(modPhase)
    idx = 10.0 * math.exp(-t / 0.22)

    fL = f * (1.0 - 0.0035)
    fR = f * (1.0 + 0.0035)
    phaseL += twopi * fL / sr
    phaseR += twopi * fR / sr

    laserL = math.sin(phaseL + idx * mod)
    laserR = math.sin(phaseR + idx * mod)

    # A second "ping" layer to feel more UI-like
    e_ping = env_perc(max(0.0, t - 0.09), 0.003, 0.22)
    ping_f = 1760.0
    ping = math.sin(twopi * ping_f * t + 0.35 * math.sin(twopi * 12.0 * t))

    # Shimmer chord bed (starts slightly after the ping)
    chord = 0.0
    if t > 0.12:
        tp = t - 0.12
        e_ch = env_perc(tp, 0.020, 0.95)
        trem = 0.85 + 0.15 * math.sin(twopi * 5.0 * t)
        for j, cf in enumerate(ch_freqs):
            # gentle detune for width
            detL = 1.0 + (-0.004 + 0.002 * j)
            detR = 1.0 + (0.004 - 0.002 * j)
            ch_phases_L[j] += twopi * (cf * detL) / sr
            ch_phases_R[j] += twopi * (cf * detR) / sr
            # add a small inharmonic partial for futuristic glassiness
            part = 0.60 * math.sin(ch_phases_L[j]) + 0.18 * math.sin(2.03 * ch_phases_L[j])
            part_r = 0.60 * math.sin(ch_phases_R[j]) + 0.18 * math.sin(2.03 * ch_phases_R[j])
            L[i] += 0.18 * e_ch * trem * part
            R[i] += 0.18 * e_ch * trem * part_r

    # Airy high-passed noise swoosh
    n0 = random.random() * 2.0 - 1.0
    hp = hp_alpha * (hp + n0 - prev_noise)
    prev_noise = n0
    e_air = env_perc(t, 0.002, 0.12)
    air = hp * e_air * 0.07

    # Sparkles
    for (t0, dur, sf, amp, pan) in spark_events:
        if t < t0:
            break
        if t0 <= t <= t0 + dur:
            u = (t - t0) / dur
            e = (1.0 - u) ** 2
            s = math.sin(twopi * sf * t) * e * amp
            # pan: -1 left, +1 right
            pL = math.cos((pan + 1.0) * math.pi / 4.0)
            pR = math.sin((pan + 1.0) * math.pi / 4.0)
            L[i] += s * pL
            R[i] += s * pR

    # Mix main layers
    sL = 0.62 * e_main * laserL + 0.23 * e_ping * ping + air
    sR = 0.62 * e_main * laserR + 0.23 * e_ping * ping + air

    L[i] += sL
    R[i] += sR

# Echo / spatial taps

def add_delay(buf, delay_s, gain):
    d = int(sr * delay_s)
    if d <= 0:
        return
    for i in range(d, len(buf)):
        buf[i] += buf[i - d] * gain

add_delay(L, 0.050, 0.30)
add_delay(R, 0.052, 0.30)
add_delay(L, 0.103, 0.17)
add_delay(R, 0.108, 0.17)

# Mild digital gloss: blend a gently quantized signal

def blend_quantized(buf, steps=96, mix=0.08):
    for i, x in enumerate(buf):
        q = round(x * steps) / steps
        buf[i] = x * (1.0 - mix) + q * mix

blend_quantized(L)
blend_quantized(R)

# Soft limiter and normalize
peak = max(max(abs(x) for x in L), max(abs(x) for x in R)) or 1.0
scale = 0.92 / peak

for i in range(n):
    # soft clip
    l = math.tanh(L[i] * 1.25) * scale
    r = math.tanh(R[i] * 1.25) * scale
    L[i] = l
    R[i] = r

with wave.open(out_path, 'wb') as wf:
    wf.setnchannels(2)
    wf.setsampwidth(2)
    wf.setframerate(sr)
    frames = bytearray()
    for i in range(n):
        vl = int(max(-1.0, min(1.0, L[i])) * 32767)
        vr = int(max(-1.0, min(1.0, R[i])) * 32767)
        frames += struct.pack('<hh', vl, vr)
    wf.writeframes(frames)

print(out_path)
print('bytes', os.path.getsize(out_path))
PY","workdir":"/home/kei/.codex","timeout_ms":100000}
